results.title: Broken Hill: a mining history 1883-1983
results.creator_credit: Terence McMahon, CRA, North Broken Hill Holdings and Terence McMahon Productions
results.brief_description: Provides a history of the Broken Hill mining industry from 1883 to the present day, incorporating documentary footage and stills of the early days, as well as comments by historian Geoffrey Blainey. Notes the early strike; the impact of technology and science in the 1920s and 30s; the mass production of fighter aircraft by BHP in the 1930s; the opening of the silver-lead smelter at Port Pirie and the steel industry at Newcastle; the introduction of company housing, health schemes and lead bonuses in the 1950s and 60s; and the intensive exploratory drilling’s for further ore deposits in the 1970s and 80s. Photography by David Olney. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Broken highway [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Laurie McInnes, Richard Mason and Black Ray Films
results.brief_description: A group of sailors aboard a merchant ship gamble and booze their way towards the Australian Coast. Among them are handsome young Angel (Aden Young), a winner to every game that Tatt’s (David Field) loses. Max (Dennis Miller), an Ancient Mariner who is close to death, instructs Angel to deliver a package to his old home in Honeyfield, Queensland, the place he remembers as paradise. He also gives him a bag of opium to appease sinister landowner Kidd (Norman Kaye). What awaits Angel is far from the tropical paradise of Max’s recollecting, although the presence of an attractive woman, Catherine (Claudia Karvan), helps matters. To confound matters and add to the inhospitability of the place, Tatt’s arrives to settle to settle a score. Cast includes Bill Hunter, Dennis Miller and David Field.

results.title: Broken down bus
results.creator_credit: Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: An old bus lies decaying in a yard, rendered obsolete by a fleet of modern coaches. But the bus is sold and after much restoration finds new life in a kindergarten playground. Suitable for lower primary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre

results.title: Broadway bound
results.creator_credit: Paul Bogart, Terry Nelson, ABC-TV (Australia) and a k a Productions
results.brief_description: This made for television production forms the third part of an “autobiographical” trilogy of the renowned American playwright Neil Simon - “Brighton Beach memoirs” being the first in the trilogy followed by “Biloxi blues”. Jonathan Silverman (Brighton Beach memoirs) returns as Eugene Jerome, Neil simon’s alter ego, while the role of Eugene’s older brother Stanley (played by Corey Parker) is based on Simon’s brother and early writing partner, Mel. The scene is set in Brighton Beach, New York in 1948 where three generations of the one family strive to live under the same roof. The Jerome brothers are attempting to fulfil their dreams of fame and fortune as comedy writers, the relationship between their mother Kate (Anne Bancroft) and father Jack (Jerry Orbach) is disintegrating rapidly and their aging grandfather Ben (Hume Cronyn) is faced with his own private dilemmas. The beauty of this film is in the witty and at times ascerbic script which is equally supported by superb performances from the cast as a whole. Screenplay by Neil Simon based on his play.

results.title: Broad waterways
results.creator_credit: Kenneth J. Fairbairn, Stewart McAllister and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: A film about Britain’s channel system, concentrating on the North Eastern Division, based in Leeds. It shows the redevelopment of the channels, locks, and docks to increase the efficiency of water transportation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kenneth J. Fairbairn, Stewart McAllister and British Transport Films

results.title: British Transport Films. 1. The Classics
results.creator_credit: Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: British Transport Films (BTF) began in May 1949 boasting one of Britain’s leading documentary filmmakers, Edgar Anstey, as its head. Between 1950 and 1980 a huge range of quality films were produced with many gaining top awards at various film festivals. This is a compilation of a selection of four films, digitally remastered by the British Film Institute, demonstrating the diversity and high calibre of BTF as a production company. Elizabethan express: From King’s Cross Station, London, to Waverley Station, Edinburgh, is 393 miles. The Elizabethan - a summertime express - does this journey in six and a half hours non-stop - the longest daily non-stop run in the world to be timed at over 60 mph in 1954. This film is about one of those runs and the people behind the service. (See also Title Code 003232 16mm) Snowdrift at Bleath Gill: A freight train becomes snowbound in the West-Morland hills in Northern England. The Motive Power, Operating and Engineering Departments of British Transport go to work with snow-ploughs to reach the trapped train. Working through the night the team dig clear, and thaw out moving parts, and finally two engines help to clear the line. (See also Title Code 009948 16mm) Train time: An account of the operation of British Railways. The integration of goods and passenger services calls for a constant review of time-tables to meet the varying local needs. (See also Title Code 011098 16mm) Forward to first principles: Tells the history of freight railways and the laying of iron lines, of the impact on the geography and landscape of Great Britain and of the age of computer technology and remote control replacing manual labour.

results.title: Britain is a garden
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Anthony Gilkison, British Travel and Holiday Association and Rayant Pictures
results.brief_description: A colorful array of floral gardens in Britain. Different styles of flower cultivation are illustrated, ranging from the wild loveliness of early spring flowers in the Scilly Isles to the delicacy of rose gardens in Northern Ireland; from London’s roof-top and window-box displays to the planned landscapes which are so much a feature of historic country houses in Britain. Includes the Chelsea Flower Show. Narrated by Deryck Guyler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Durst, Anthony Gilkison, British Travel and Holiday Association and Rayant Pictures
